qas.question: What were the traditional building materials on Tuvalu?
What type of trees provided lumber for building on Tuvalu?
What building material did coconut provide?
What construction feature was lacking in Tuvaluan building?
From what was rope made for tying buildings together?

context: The traditional buildings of Tuvalu used <a0_0>plants and trees<a0_0/> from the native <a1_0>broadleaf forest<a1_0/>, including timber from: Pouka, (Hernandia peltata); Ngia or Ingia bush, (Pemphis acidula); Miro, (Thespesia populnea); Tonga, (Rhizophora mucronata); Fau or Fo fafini, or woman's fibre tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus). and <a2_0>fibre<a2_0/> from: coconut; Ferra, native fig (Ficus aspem); Fala, screw pine or Pandanus. The buildings were constructed without <a3_0>nails<a3_0/> and were lashed and tied together with a plaited sennit rope that was handmade from <a4_0>dried coconut fibre<a4_0/>.
